Award.AwardTitle: NRI-Small: Multifunctional Electroactive Polymers for Muscle-Like Actuation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to develop a new, bistable electroactive polymer that combines large actuation strain and energy density with variable stiffness and bistable deformation. The technical approach of the project involves: (1) synthesizing new polymers comprising interpenetrating polymers network to achieve stable, high-strain actuation; (2) investigating ultrathin carbon nanotube coatings for fault tolerance and enhanced operation reliability; (3) reducing the driving voltages of electroactive polymers to around 200 V by synthesizing new polymers with high dielectric permittivity as well as by developing processing techniques to produce high-quality polymer thin films; and (4) fabricating compact modular actuators that can be readily integrated into robotic systems. The potential transformative technical impact of this project is a radically new actuator material that can reproduce the structural, actuation, and sensing functions of muscles, and can be inserted into a broad range of robotic systems for locomotion and manipulation.

This project will develop a new actuator material based on a bistable electroactive polymer that behaves like an artificial muscle, and offers a combination of attributes that future robotic systems demand including power output that outperforms human skeletal muscle, flexibility, quietness, and biocompatibility. Actuators based on the new polymer material enable the design of robotic systems that interact with people, such as assistive prosthesis or assistive devices for people with disability, humanoid robots for elderly in-home care, and surgical robots to save lives. The material can also be used for industrial automation for increased production efficiency. This project includes significant outreach and educational activities. It will provide summer research intern opportunities for under-represented minority high school students each year. Undergraduate and graduate students will participate in the proposed research to gain hands-on research experience, as well as analytical, communication, and inter-personal skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed to develop a new, bistable electroactive polymer that combines large actuation strain and energy density with variable stiffness and bistable deformation, with overarching objective of creatig new smart materials that can reproduce certain muscle functions and enable new soft robotic applications. The project activities were focused on (1) synthesizing new dielectric elastomers with high dielectric constant to lower the operation voltage, (2) developing a new bistable electroactive polymer with low transition temperature suitable for wearable and on-skin applications, (3) synthesizing a new dielectric elastomer with variable stiffness, and (4) developing a tubular dielectric elastomer actuator for active fluidic control.

A significant outcome is the successful synthesis of a new dielectric elastomer with variable stiffness. This is a major step forward in our effort to create an electroactive elastomer that exhibit a range of stress-strain outputs in similar fashion as natural muscle does.  Both sensors and actuators based on this material could be operated in both high strain mode and high force output mode. In the effort to lower the driving voltage, we successfully synthesized a dielectric elastomer nanocomposite containing a high loading content of aluminum nanoparticles to more than double the dielectric constant. New progress has also been made in improving the performance of the BSEP polymer to be more suitable for wearable and on-skin applications. The new tubular actuators provide a novel soft electroactive fluidic channel.  

The project provided training and professional training opportunities for 8 graduate students (4 being female), 4 undergraduate students (2 being female), and 2 high school students, who carried out the majority of the project research activities. 4 PhD students attended the Electroactive Polymer training school held in Neuchatel, Switzerland, 2 in 2013, and 2 in 2015.

 


Last Modified: 02/10/2016
Modified by: Qibing Pei

A significant outcome is the successful synthesis of a new dielectric elastomer with variable stiffness. This is a major step forward in our effort to create an electroactive elastomer that exhibit a range of stress-strain outputs in similar fashion as natural muscle does. Both sensors and actuators based on this material could be operated in both high strain mode and high force output mode. In the effort to lower the driving voltage, we successfully synthesized a dielectric elastomer nanocomposite containing a high loading content of aluminum nanoparticles to more than double the dielectric constant. New progress has also been made in improving the performance of the BSEP polymer to be more suitable for wearable and on-skin applications.
